Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-cost highly-reflective and light scattering dielectric nanoparticle based thin films for solar cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to demonstrate the feasibility of an innovative concept in using highly reflective and light scattering nanoparticle thin films as solar cell back reflectors with the goal to replace high-vacuum processing techniques. Conventional back reflectors consist of a sputtered metal film, which requires high capital cost for large scale systems and frequent downtime due to maintenance, cleaning, and replacing of the sputtering targets. In addition, sputtered metal back reflectors can have adverse effects on the solar cell device. Solar cells with silver back reflectors can achieve record efficiencies, but silver migrates into the absorber material and deteriorates the performance and reliability. Further, silver does not adhere well to substrates used in solar cell manufacturing and readily oxidizes reducing its reflectivity. Instead, sputtered aluminum back reflectors are typically used in thin film solar industry, but aluminum absorbs light in a crucial portion of the sunlight spectrum resulting in moderate performance gains. This project will use the lower-cost electrophoretic deposition method to grow dielectric nanoparticle thin films. The anticipated result is a manufacturable nanoparticle back reflector that is equally as reflective as silver for high efficiency and reliable solar cells.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to produce high efficiency thin film solar cells using nanoparticle-based back reflectors. The proposed nanoparticle-based back reflector can be fabricated using the atmospheric electrophoretic deposition method and replaces the conventional approach of using high vacuum sputtering of metals, which can be expensive, time consuming, energy intensive, and have poor material utilization. Engineered nanoparticle-based films are an ideal way to obtain very high light scattering and reflective surfaces, which are required properties of back reflectors in high efficiency solar cells. A combination of high solar cell performance and low-cost manufacturing methods means that the proposed nanoparticle-based back reflector will be well positioned to succeed in a highly competitive solar market, which had sales of $82 billion in 2010. Beyond solar, additional applications for highly engineered nanoparticle-based films include backlight reflectors for high efficiency flat panel displays, superhydrophobic surfaces for self-cleaning and water shedding applications, textured/porous structures for electronic devices, and photonic structures for electro-optical devices. This project will promote technology-based economic development in the upper Midwest. Collaboration with South Dakota State University will train graduate and undergraduate students in nanomaterial science and engineering to advance the capabilities of the future workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through Phases I/IB of the National Science Foundation Small Business Innovation Research program, Applied NanoFilms used its patent-pending method to deposit highly engineered nanoparticle-based films and fabricated highly reflective and light scattering back reflectors for thin film solar cells. Applied NanoFilms’ deposition method is a rapid, low-cost and large-area way to produce uniform and conformal nanoparticle-based films with strong potential to be an alternative to conventional high vacuum thin film deposition technologies.

Nanoparticle-based film properties can be engineered by depositing one or more layers of nanoparticles of different material types and sizes, and various structures, such as holes and pillars, can be engineered into the film as well. For example: maximum diffuse reflection is obtained using nanoparticles with few hundred nanometer diameter but the film’s surface roughness can be reduced by depositing a second layer of nanoparticles with smaller diameter. Small surface roughness is desired for better compatibility with subsequently deposited solar absorber layers. And electrical resistance of the film can be decreased by using highly conductive nanoparticles deposited into holes in the nanoparticle-film creating electrical vias for photo-generated current to conduct from solar absorber to contact.

Dielectric nanoparticles were deposited into dense, thick films and were shown to have higher diffuse reflectance over the critical visible to infrared spectrum of light resulting in higher photocurrent and higher efficiency of a single-junction bifacial amorphous silicon solar cell compared to conventionally used metal-based back reflectors. The solar cell and subsequent characterization was provided by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Efficiency improvements of 30% or greater are expected for triple-junction thin film silicon solar cells using our nanoparticle-based back reflector technology compared to the sputtered aluminum and zinc oxide buffer layers currently being used in commercial production. In addition, the nanoparticle-based films demonstrated strong adhesion and strong mechanical durability as determined by scratch, tape and drop tests and its ability to withstand cracking while bending on a flexible substrate.

Our back reflector technology showed higher photocurrent and efficiency compared to the back reflector technology currently used in record high efficiency thin film silicon solar cells: sputtered silver and zinc oxide buffer layers. This was due to our nanoparticle-based films having highly scattered reflected light promoting light trapping leading to higher light absorption and solar cell performance. In comparison, metal based films are specular reflectors meaning they are mirror-like. Further, silver back reflectors are unable to be used in commercial products due to numerous reliability issues.

Nanoparticle-based films have strong potential in the marketplace not only on a low-cost basis, but also as a way to achieve higher performance and additional beneficial properties, such as diffuse vs. specular reflection, that are not easily obtainable with traditional thin film deposition and processing technologies. Many applications, such as solar cells, batteries, supercapacitors, sensors, photonics, electrical devices, and many others, can benefit from nanoparticle-films and the unique properties they provide. Applied NanoFilms patent-pending technology and experienced know-how can lead the way to realizing low-cost and high-quality nanoparticle-based films.
